knownFor: King of Uruk, hero of the Epic of Gilgamesh, a foundational text of world literature.
Founder of the Akkadian Empire, the first ancient Semitic empire in Mesopotamia.
Sixth king of the First Babylonian Dynasty, famous for Hammurabi's Code, one of the earliest legal codes.
Third pharaoh of the Nineteenth Dynasty of Egypt, considered one of the greatest and most powerful pharaohs.
A Chinese philosopher and political figure whose teachings and philosophy became the foundation of East Asian culture and society.
Founder of the Achaemenid Empire, the first Persian empire, renowned for his conquests and human rights policies.
King of the ancient Greek kingdom of Macedon, he created one of the largest empires in the ancient world, stretching from Greece to India.
A Roman general and statesman who played a critical role in the events that led to the demise of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire.
The first Roman Emperor, who led Rome's transformation from a republic to an empire, establishing the Pax Romana.
An Indian emperor of the Maurya Dynasty who ruled almost all of the Indian subcontinent and is credited with the widespread propagation of Buddhism.
Carthaginian general and statesman, considered one of the greatest military commanders in history for his leadership in the Second Punic War.
Roman Emperor who legalized Christianity throughout the empire and founded the city of Constantinople.
King of the Franks and founder of the Carolingian Empire, uniting much of Western and Central Europe.
King of Wessex who successfully defended his kingdom against the Viking invasion, laying the groundwork for the unification of England.
A Persian polymath regarded as one of the most significant physicians, astronomers, and thinkers of the Islamic Golden Age.
Founder and first Great Khan of the Mongol Empire, which became the largest contiguous empire in history.
Venetian merchant and explorer who traveled along the Silk Road and whose travels were chronicled in 'The Travels of Marco Polo'.
Moroccan explorer and scholar who traveled more than 75,000 miles across the Islamic world and beyond, recording his journeys in 'The Rihla'.
A polymath of the Italian Renaissance whose genius spanned invention, painting, sculpting, architecture, science, and more. Famous works include the 'Mona Lisa' and 'The Last Supper'.
Queen of England and Ireland, her reign is known as the Elizabethan era, a period of great artistic and literary flourishing, and English global exploration.
Italian astronomer and physicist who played a major role in the scientific revolution. His improvements to the telescope and support for Copernicanism changed the understanding of the cosmos.
English playwright, poet, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world's pre-eminent dramatist.
English physicist and mathematician who is widely regarded as one of the most influential scientists of all time. Key work includes 'Principia Mathematica'.
First President of the United States, Commander-in-Chief of the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War.

French military and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution and led several successful campaigns during the French Revolutionary Wars. As Emperor of the French, he dominated European and global affairs for over a decade.
Queen of the United Kingdom and Empress of India, her reign of 63 years was a period of great industrial, cultural, political, scientific, and military change.
associatedWith: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland

knownFor: A conservative Prussian statesman who dominated German and European affairs from the 1860s until 1890. He engineered the unification of Germany in 1871.
Indian lawyer, anti-colonial nationalist, and political ethicist who employed nonviolent resistance to lead the successful campaign for India's independence from British Rule.
Founder and first president of the Republic of Turkey, credited with the establishment of the modern Turkish state.
Russian revolutionary and head of government of the Soviet Union from 1917 to 1924. He played a key role in the October Revolution and the establishment of the world's first communist state.
Leader of the Nazi Party and dictator of Nazi Germany from 1933 to 1945. He was a central figure in World War II and the Holocaust.
British Prime Minister during World War II, known for his wartime leadership and inspiring speeches.
32nd President of the United States, serving during the Great Depression and World War II. He led the nation through a period of economic and global crisis.
South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and first President of South Africa. He was a central figure in the struggle against apartheid and a global icon of peace and reconciliation.
German-born theoretical physicist who developed the theory of relativity and is considered one of the most influential scientists of all time.
associatedWith: Germany, Switzerland, United States of America

knownFor: Polish-French physicist and chemist, and the first woman to win a Nobel Prize. Her pioneering research on radioactivity laid the foundation for modern nuclear physics.
American writer and biochemist, considered one of the 'Big Three' science fiction writers. He wrote or edited more than 500 books.
